docs.title: Welcome to Qulka
docs.text:
The quote "Give me control of a nation's money and I care not who makes its laws" is frequently attributed to Mayer Amschel Rothschild, the founder of the Rothschild banking dynasty. This statement, often paraphrased as "Permit me to issue and control the money of a nation, and I care not who makes its laws," underscores the perceived supremacy of financial power over legislative authority. It suggests that control over a nation's monetary system—through the issuance, regulation, and flow of money—grants immense influence over policy, economic stability, and political outcomes, effectively allowing those in control to shape governance without direct legislative power. Despite its widespread circulation, there is no verifiable primary source confirming that Rothschild actually made this statement; the earliest known attribution dates to 1935, and the quote is considered apocryphal by historians. The sentiment, however, reflects a long-standing critique of centralized financial power, with similar ideas traced back to earlier figures like Andrew Fletcher and Sir Philip Sidney.

— AI-generated

docs.title: We, in the West, live in an oligarchy
docs.text:
As Michael Hudson explains (and pretty much anyone can tell from daily experience), western liberal democracy has failed if one judges by the degree to which it has attained its declared objectives. It has, for all practical purposes, become an oligarchic system. This happened because the rich were able to capture our political institutions, theoretically designed to be resilient by a system of checks and balances. With hindsight, we can even affirm that those checks and balances either totally missed some critical points, or were deliberately meant from the beginning to hinder, if not eliminate, the capacity of societies to control the ages-old issue of wealth concentration. (Which had, by the way, been solved in other societies; to give what could perhaps be the most familiar entry-point to such matters for a westerner, we invite unaware readers to ponder the fact that, originally, the jubilee was precisely such a tool).

This simple truth provides us with a lecture key to decode the claim, duly repeated at every opportunity in western mass media, that we're witnessing a struggle between "democracies" and "autocratic regimes". What they actually mean is that in some nations (notably, China and Russia) political systems have emerged that are building immunity against being captured by western financial interests. They are thus becoming sovereign, and putting an end to several centuries of global western dominance that has been used to exploit people and deprive them of their resources, to the benefit of a few.

Here we're concerned with understanding the root cause of all of this, in order to be able to do something about it (other than waiting for a multipolar world order to emerge and hope it is more benign). But the issue is, of course, very multi-faceted. There are cultural traits, historical events, geographic factors... Here we take the standpoint that, for current practical purposes, the blame needs to be put on the way credit is managed. This should mean that economists are in a good position to fix things out, and we must therefore spend a few words on why this has not happened.

docs.title: Academy
docs.text:
It is difficult to get a man to understand something when his salary depends on his not understanding it. This observation highlights how financial incentives can create a powerful barrier to objective understanding, as an individual's livelihood may be directly tied to maintaining a particular belief or ignorance about a subject. The quote, often attributed to Upton Sinclair, underscores the challenge of persuading someone whose income is contingent upon not grasping the truth, whether in corporate, political, or professional contexts. This principle applies broadly, from executives in industries with environmental impacts to professionals in regulated sectors who may resist change that threatens their role.

— AI-generated

You'll likely have a very hard time explaining to an economist that the so-called "independence of the Central Bank" is an ideological tool meant to rationalize and justify the fact that private financial institutions in western countries have: (1) acquired an unfair monopoly on the issuance of money; and (2) used it to misappropriate the surplus of our economic activity. The way this is done, once stripped of its byzantine technicalities, is so outrageous that it allegedly led Henry Ford to say:

"It is well enough that people of the nation do not understand our banking and monetary system, for if they did, I believe there would be a revolution before tomorrow morning". While there is no definitive record of Ford uttering these exact words, the sentiment aligns with a passage from his 1922 book My Life and Work, where he expressed concern that the public's lack of understanding of financial systems protects the integrity of sound money, as people are naturally conservative about money and would likely react strongly if they fully grasped how financial institutions manipulate the system. The quote reflects a belief that the complexity and opacity of banking—particularly the ability of financiers to create money through mechanisms like credit and leverage—could provoke widespread outrage if exposed. This idea is echoed by others, such as economist John Kenneth Galbraith, who noted that the process by which banks create money is so simple that it repels the mind, suggesting that the system's mechanics are deliberately obscured.

— AI-generated

So, how is it possible that economists have not collectively raised their voice and guided politicians to fix the problem? Not only that: they've built a supposedly sound theoretical edifice that protects the system, recurring to ethics, philosophy, darwinian evolution, game theory, stochastic differential equations and so on. Steve Keen, among other authoritative voices that could be mentioned here, has written a detailed debunking of the pseudo-scientific state that mainstream economic theory has reached.

There is one aspect of the story whose importance must not be underestimated. Western culture values ideas and longs for the absolute and eternal, often to the detriment of facts on the ground. It easily becomes ideological and detached from reality, grossly diverging from the scientific spirit that it paradoxically claims to champion. Economics has certainly fallen prey to this, and the push for serious consideration of actual facts has come from different camps. At any rate, regardless of the precise dynamics (which are certainly interesting on their own) that brought us here, the bottom line is that economy (and, to varying degrees, other fields of academia) has been captured.

docs.title: Common sense
docs.text:
Yes, common sense has been captured too. Otherwise, Ford's feared revolution would already have happened. But how is this possible? You can fool some people sometimes, but you can't fool all the people all the time, right? Well, as Gramsci explains, that may be true, but there's a continuous struggle for what society as a whole accepts and takes for granted. Having control over what people read and watch plays a critical role. As we can expect, western oligarcs understand this very well and have thus captured mass media.

With the advent of the internet, things became interesting. At some point, people thought we'd reach a stage of unprecedented freedom, democracy and universal well-being thanks to the increased availability of knowledge and long-range people-to-people exchanges. It indeed became harder to hide facts as the information space opened, but at the same time other harmful consequences started to reveal themselves:

  1. We were overwhelmed by low-quality content, and the simultaneous discredit of traditionally authoritative voices (politicians, reporters, scientists) led to a further erosion of the notion of truth itself (already damaged by several factors, among which well-intentioned cultural relativism and a permanent push to value appearance over essence in a consumer society).
  2. Profilation and content customization fragmented society into opinion bubbles with little cross-fertilization, leading to echo chambers that reinforce ideologies up to the point of extremism.

Both phenomenona are being taken advantage of by our oligarchy. The weakening of our grasp on truth has enabled a direct attack on it by politicians and functionaries who claim, with a sad degree of success, that anything they don't like is "fake news". Big Tech took marketing techniques to a new level and their degree of influence on political movements and electoral campaigns grew even more. Now, oligarcs try to regain whatever narrative control they lost via deplatforming and outright censorship. They can do it, because they own the spaces where virtual exchanges happen (social networks and virtual markets). As Yanis Varoufakis argues, capitalism is evolving into a stage of technofeudalism.

At the same time, peer-to-peer technologies have been developed and people are trying to defend the original ethos of the web. The battle for social networks might not be lost.

docs.title: Credit
docs.text: Yes, credit has been captured too. But we need to undertand a few things before getting into that.

docs.title: Regarding Money and Central Banks
docs.text: Besides their obvious economic importance, central banks have considerable political power. Richard Werner has studied this phenomenon focusing particularily on the case of Japan. Now, a first-principles explanation of this calls for a deep understanding of what money actually is. But if economists have been captured, whom should we turn to here? Beautifully enough, it's been for anthropologists to answer the call.

docs.title: Money
docs.text:
As a first observation, one needs to realize that there won't be a single, unified understanding of something which we've grown to take for granted, shows up on all levels of human activity (from buying bread to waging wars), and is confusingly very concrete and very abstract at the same time. Depending on the perspective that one adopts, the answer will throw a different light on money. Let's mention a few possibilities:

  • Economists like to take a descriptive approach and say that money does three things: serves as a mean of exchange, provides an accounting unit, and constitutes a value reserve.
  • From a physical perspective, given that money flows in the opposite direction as physical exchanges (be it products or services), it should be a (perceived) measure of negative entropy. When an imbalance between entropy flow and money flow occurs, the system is not stable and price adjustments should eventually take place. Note also that there is a global multiplicative symmetry, a fact that explains the possibility of price inflation.
  • Noting the basic fact that money is a social convention and plays an important role in the organization of a society, we can observe a really fundamental property: money is that with which taxes are paid (Chartalism).
  • But what about actual history? Money is something we humans invented; paying attention to why and how is certainly bound to result in fundamental insights. In his book Debt: the first 5,000 years David Graeber explains that money was actually born as a symbolic way to settle debts, and the debts we were originally interested in had more to do with honor than with commerce. It was only later that money begun to be used for material exchanges, and this leads to a crucial realization: economies actually work on credit.

docs.title: ...and Credit
docs.text:
It's easy to understand how economies worked for millenia, before central banks were created and acquired a monopoly on the issuance of money. Say you have goats, make cheese and take it to some grocery store for distribution. Without money, what the store administration would do (if you agree) is to take note of the fact that they owe you the value of your cheese, and allow you to eventually have your fair retribution by giving you credit to buy stuff on the store. Instead of (or in addition to) taking note of that in an internal book, they would give you paper notes that can be redeemed for products. Then, as a matter of fact, you're not forced to use those notes on the store: you can, say, go to the hairdresser and pay for a haircut with them. As long as they know and trust both you and the grocery store, there will be no problems with that. And there you go: money has been put in circulation, just by a simple chain of community credit-based actions.

One can raise lots of non-critical security and trust-related objections, but the fact is that things have worked like this, and now we do have the tecnological means to make it safely work again, at scale. Why we stopped doing it that way is another question, and the case can be made (see David Graeber again) that there were no problems with malicious user behavior, but simply an organized push by banks to acquire a monopoly on money issuance.

Now, this is no place to explain the inner workings of banks (fractional reserves, central bank monetary policy tools, etcetera). We leave it to the reader to fill in the gaps. The points that we want to emphasize are:

  1. In order for the economy to grow (say, you incremeanting PIB by bringing your cheese to the market), mechanisms for providing liquidity (in the form of credit managed either by the community or a private bank) must exist.
  2. When the community provides credit, no one is lending money and therefore no interest rates apply: the resulting growth (assuming the cheese was of good quality and someone buys it; otherwise, the result would be inflation) is a win-win proposition where the community as a whole benefits. When the bank provides credit (and make no mistake: it will not lend existing money, but create it out of nowhere), it will do so with an interest rate and will, therefore, misapropriate the excedent systemically produced by the financed economic activity.

docs.title: The big mistake of cyptocurrencies
docs.text:
Cryptocurrencies were born out of mistrust on centralization in general, and centralized monetary policy in particular. However, they are based on a conception of money as bullion. People thought we needed something like gold, but virtual. Without getting into the troubling fact that, as a means of exchange, cryptocurrencies are very energy-inefficient (bitcoin's ledger mechanism, based on "proof of work", consumes ridiculous amount of energy; other cryptocurrencies use "proof of stake" which is better, but still bad), let's point out that they are barking up at the wrong tree:

  1. Having a fixed supply of money in circulation is a problem, not a solution. Thus, cryptocurrencies are just financial speculation assets, not quite able to fulfill the role of money.
  2. The problem with central banks is not that they can create money, but that they are controlled by oligarchs that put the fresh money in circulation through financial institutions that become de-facto owners of the emergent wealth in a complex economy.

docs.title: Dangers ahead
docs.text:
Pointing out the great danger ahead is good to sharpen our sense of urgency and need for strategic thinking as we move forward. Our oligarchy can go, and seems indeed to be going full authoritarian. Technology is giving them immensely powerful tools that can be used for social control:

  • Private social networks. They are showing their willingness to keep narrative control by deplatforming people with inconvenient points of view. A substantial part of the population seems to be OK with it, in the belief that what they're doing is "fighting disinformation".
  • Blockchain and virtual currencies. Debanking is becoming more and more widespread, and we might end up having no freedom to earn and spend money. We could basically revert to a hi-tech version of company tokens or scrip redeemable only at company stores for specific items, with the added "feature" that tokens are personal and social behavior can alter their value.
  • Artificial inteligence. Currently, it requires huge infrastructure to run, is extremely capital and energy-intensive to develop, and provides therefore even more possibilities of monopolization and consequent abuse. AI might become the backbone of all of our economy, so this is rather scary.

docs.title: Our grain of sand
docs.text:
So, we really need to get our act together. What this project is about, our grain of sand in contributing to respond to this situation, is a p2p, serverless tool for local social networks to:

  1. Freely express themselves, thereby organically creating their own "narrative" or understanding of the world.
  2. Take ownership of their emergent, systemic wealth creation by enabling management of currency issuance and credit allocation.

docs.title: Antonio Gramsci on Hegemony
docs.text:
AI-generated

Antonio Gramsci's theory of hegemony describes how a dominant social group, particularly the bourgeoisie in capitalist societies, maintains power not solely through coercion or economic force, but by securing the active consent of subordinate classes through ideological leadership. This consent is achieved by embedding the values, norms, and interests of the ruling class into the cultural fabric of society, making them appear as common sense or natural. Hegemony operates across two key realms: the state, which represents the apparatus of coercion (such as courts, police, and military), and civil society, which includes institutions like schools, media, churches, and cultural organizations that shape public opinion and cultural norms.

Gramsci argued that hegemony is not a static condition but a dynamic and ongoing process that must be constantly negotiated and maintained, as subordinate groups can resist or challenge the dominant ideology. He distinguished between the "war of maneuver," a direct and violent assault on state power akin to the Russian Revolution, and the "war of position," a slower, more sustained struggle to transform civil society by building a counter-hegemonic culture and winning ideological leadership over time. This shift in strategy reflects his belief that in developed capitalist societies, revolution requires first reshaping the cultural and ideological terrain before seizing formal political power.

A central element of Gramsci's theory is the concept of the "historic bloc," a coalition of social forces united under the leadership of a dominant class, which provides the basis for consent to the existing social order. This bloc is sustained through a nexus of institutions, social relations, and ideas that reproduce the hegemony of the ruling class. Gramsci also emphasized the role of intellectuals in maintaining or challenging hegemony, distinguishing between traditional intellectuals, who typically reinforce the status quo, and organic intellectuals—those emerging from the working class—who help develop a counter-hegemonic culture and organize the masses to challenge dominant ideologies.

Gramsci's concept of hegemony was developed in his Prison Notebooks, written during his imprisonment under Mussolini’s Fascist regime, where he critiqued the economic determinism of classical Marxism and proposed a more nuanced understanding of power that integrates cultural, moral, and ideological dimensions. He argued that the bourgeoisie maintains its dominance by balancing coercion with consent, often by addressing the interests of subaltern classes to secure their support, thereby creating a stable equilibrium. This idea of hegemony as "predominance by consent" underscores the importance of ideological leadership in sustaining social order, a framework that remains highly influential in contemporary political theory, cultural studies, and analyses of media and social movements.

docs.title: David Graeber on Money
docs.text:
AI-generated

David Graeber, an economic anthropologist, challenges the conventional narrative that money originated from barter systems. He argues that barter is a myth, as there is no historical or anthropological evidence of societies relying on direct exchange of goods before the advent of money. Instead, Graeber posits that debt and credit systems predate money, with early human societies operating on reciprocal gift exchange and social obligations, where giving something creates a tacit debt to reciprocate. This sense of obligation—“I owe you one”—is the foundational concept from which more formalized systems of accounting and value measurement evolved.

According to Graeber, money emerged not as a medium to replace barter, but as a unit of account within complex administrative systems, particularly in ancient Mesopotamia around 3200 BC, where temples and palaces used standardized units to manage resources and labor. These early systems were based on credit, not commodity exchange. The idea that money is a social construct—essentially a promise or IOU—underpins his view, with money functioning as a way to quantify and manage social relations, particularly debt. He emphasizes that money is not inherently a physical object with intrinsic value but rather a social and linguistic tool for measuring value.

Graeber also highlights the deep historical connection between debt and morality, noting that in many ancient languages, words for debt, guilt, and sin were identical. This linguistic overlap reflects how debt has long been framed as a moral failing, a concept exploited by rulers and institutions to justify power and control. He traces the evolution of money through periods where credit dominated (Chartalist theory) and where commodity-based systems (like coinage) took precedence, showing that money’s nature has shifted historically depending on social and political contexts.

Furthermore, Graeber argues that the modern financial system is built on a foundation of debt, with most money in circulation being created through credit extended by banks. He critiques the idea that money is a neutral tool, asserting instead that it is deeply embedded in power structures and social relationships. His work, particularly in Debt: The First 5,000 Years, reveals that debt forgiveness and the cancellation of debts—such as the ancient Mesopotamian "clean slate" or amargi—were common mechanisms to prevent social collapse, underscoring that the history of money is inseparable from struggles over justice, freedom, and economic inequality.

docs.title: Michael Hudson on Oligarchy
docs.text:
AI-generated

Michael Hudson describes oligarchy as a central feature of Western civilization, tracing its roots to classical antiquity and arguing that it has evolved into a dominant force shaping modern economic and political systems. He defines oligarchy as "rule by the few, usually the richest One Percent," and views it as the inevitable outcome of democracy, where wealth concentrates in the hands of a small elite who then manipulate the political system to protect their interests. According to Hudson, this process is not accidental but a result of deliberate policies that favor the financial and propertied classes, leading to the dismantling of public institutions and the privatization of essential services.

Hudson emphasizes that oligarchic control is maintained through mechanisms that prevent democratic reform. He points to the U.S. political system as a prime example, where the Citizens United Supreme Court decision has enabled the wealthy to dominate elections by funding candidates and shaping party platforms, effectively creating a two-party duopoly that excludes viable third-party alternatives. This system, he argues, allows the donor class to select candidates through financial influence rather than popular vote, making the democratic process a façade. He draws a historical parallel to Rome on the eve of the Republic’s collapse, where candidates had to finance their campaigns through debt to wealthy patrons, thereby binding them to the oligarchy.

The financial sector plays a key role in entrenching oligarchy, according to Hudson. By shifting the tax burden onto labor and industry while offering tax breaks to the wealthy and financial institutions, governments create budget deficits that are financed through debt. This debt is then used as a tool of control, forcing countries to adopt austerity measures, privatize public assets, and impose economic reforms that benefit creditors. He argues that this system is not a natural economic outcome but a political choice that serves the interests of a financial elite.

Hudson also critiques the role of international institutions like the IMF and World Bank, which he claims enforce a "Washington Consensus" that forces debtor nations into austerity and economic dependency, effectively turning them into tools of U.S. financial dominance. He contends that the U.S. leverages its position as a global debtor nation to extract concessions from creditor nations, using the threat of financial chaos to maintain its economic hegemony. This form of "financial conquest" is, in his view, more destructive than military conquest because it undermines national sovereignty and economic self-determination.

In Hudson’s analysis, the cycle of political systems—monarchy, aristocracy, oligarchy, democracy, and ochlocracy—leads inevitably to a return to authoritarian rule when the populace becomes disillusioned with the failures of oligarchic democracy. He warns that without a fundamental restructuring of the political and economic system, the United States risks repeating the collapse of ancient Rome, where the oligarchy’s self-serving policies led to social unrest and the eventual rise of imperial rule. The only way to break this cycle, he suggests, is through a radical transformation of the political system, including the creation of a parliamentary democracy that allows for genuine third-party competition and challenges to the existing power structure.

docs.title: Richard Werner on Central banks
docs.text:
AI-generated

Richard Werner, a German economist and professor at the University of Winchester, is a prominent critic of central banks and their role in the global financial system. He argues that central banks are not the stabilizing institutions they claim to be, but rather amplifiers of financial instability through their manipulation of credit and interest rates. Werner contends that central banks, such as the Federal Reserve, are not government entities but private institutions owned by member banks, often controlled by powerful financial families, and thus serve the interests of a small elite rather than the public.

A central tenet of Werner’s critique is the "credit creation theory," which posits that banks create money ex nihilo—out of nothing—when they issue loans, rather than acting as mere intermediaries of existing savings. He asserts that this process is the primary driver of economic activity, with 97% of the money supply created through bank lending, while central banks create only about 3%. This challenges the mainstream economic narrative that central banks control the money supply through interest rates and reserve requirements.

Werner argues that central banks' policies, particularly interest rate manipulation, are ineffective and often counterproductive. He claims that the dominant "central bank narrative" is built on five pillars—interest rates as the main policy tool, markets in equilibrium, banks as financial intermediaries, the need for foreign borrowing to fund growth, and the necessity of deregulation and privatization—all of which he asserts lack empirical support and have been disproven by events such as the 2008 financial crisis. He further criticizes the use of models like Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium (DSGE) models, which he says failed to predict the 2008 crisis and are based on flawed assumptions.

Werner also links central banking to broader societal issues, including war and economic inequality. He claims that central banks have historically funded wars by enabling governments to borrow heavily, profiting from the resulting debt and interest payments. He suggests that this financial mechanism has been used to serve the interests of banking elites, with conflicts often being profitable for banks regardless of the outcome.

In response to these systemic flaws, Werner advocates for a decentralized economic model where money creation is democratized and tied to productive uses. He supports systems like SORA, a blockchain-based network that implements his economic ideas through an elastic token supply, democratic governance via sortition, and a focus on funding real-world productivity. He emphasizes that new money should be allocated to projects that generate tangible economic value—such as infrastructure, education, and innovation—rather than speculative assets.

Werner also warns against the potential for Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) to become tools of governmental control over individuals, advocating instead for transparent, community-driven alternatives that empower local economies and prevent plutocratic control. His vision centers on shifting power from centralized institutions to decentralized, accountable systems that prioritize economic growth through productive credit rather than speculative finance.

docs.title: Steve Keen on Economic Theory
docs.text:
AI-generated

"Debunking Economics: The Naked Emperor of the Social Sciences" is a book by economist Steve Keen that offers a comprehensive critique of mainstream neoclassical economics. Initially published in 2001 by Zed Books, a revised and expanded edition was released in 2011, incorporating updated analysis and a deeper exploration of the 2007 financial crisis. The book argues that core concepts of neoclassical economics—such as demand curves, the theory of the firm, and the idea of equilibrium—are based on flawed assumptions, lack empirical support, and are often logically inconsistent. Keen contends that these theoretical constructs fail to accurately represent real-world economic behavior and that the reliance on equilibrium models, such as those underpinning the efficient-market hypothesis, oversimplifies the dynamic and often unstable nature of actual economies.

Keen challenges fundamental principles like the law of demand, arguing that utility maximization and the aggregation of individual preferences into a collective demand curve are mathematically and conceptually unsound. He also revisits the Cambridge capital controversy, asserting that key economic concepts such as capital and profit are ill-defined and cannot be meaningfully aggregated. A central theme of the book is that mainstream economics' overreliance on simplifying assumptions—such as perfect competition and infinite market participants—leads to conclusions that are highly sensitive to these assumptions and often fail in practice. Keen further criticizes the neoclassical approach for ignoring real-world anomalies, such as the failure of rising marginal costs to hold empirically, and for dismissing contradictory evidence through doctrines like Milton Friedman’s "assumptions don’t matter" argument.

The revised edition expands on these critiques by explaining the causes and persistence of the 2007 financial crisis, which Keen attributes to the inherent instability of capitalist systems driven by debt accumulation and deflationary spirals. He advocates for alternative frameworks such as complexity economics, Marxian economics, and Austrian economics, though he acknowledges none are fully satisfactory. While some economists, like John Quiggin, acknowledge Keen raises important questions but argue his claim to have "debunked" economics is premature, others, such as George Monbiot, praise the book’s explanatory power regarding the financial crisis. Critics like Robert Murphy and Gene Callaham note Keen sometimes overreaches in his critique, but still recognize the value of the questions he poses. Keen’s work continues to influence discussions on economic theory, particularly in modeling financial instability and debt-deflation dynamics, and he remains a prominent voice in challenging the foundations of conventional economic thought.

docs.title: Yanis Varoufakis on Technofeudalism
docs.text:
AI-generated

Yanis Varoufakis, the former Greek finance minister and economist, argues in his 2023 book Technofeudalism: What Killed Capitalism that capitalism has been replaced by a new economic system he terms "technofeudalism". According to Varoufakis, major tech companies like Apple, Meta (formerly Facebook), Amazon, and Alphabet have become modern-day feudal lords, while users are reduced to "cloud serfs" who provide free labor through their data, attention, and online activity, thereby enriching these digital fiefdoms. This system is characterized not by profit derived from labor, as in capitalism, but by the extraction of "rent" — such as Apple’s 30% commission on app sales or the monetization of user attention through advertising — which he likens to the ground rent paid by medieval serfs to lords. He contends that this shift has led to a massive siphoning of wealth, with estimates suggesting 35–40% of GDP is diverted from the circular flow of income through cloud rent, undermining investment and job quality. Furthermore, Varoufakis asserts that the algorithms of these platforms are designed to maximize engagement by fostering anger and division, which harms democratic discourse and mental well-being, particularly among younger generations. He warns that this new system, sustained by central banks and governments, poses a profound threat to democracy and individual autonomy, and calls for a collective "cloud rebellion" to reclaim control over digital infrastructure and property rights.

docs.title: Jubilee and Debt Cancellation
docs.text:
AI-generated

The concept of Jubilee debt cancellation originates in the biblical Year of Jubilee described in Leviticus 25, which mandated the forgiveness of all debts, the release of those enslaved due to debt, the return of land to its original owners, and a reset of economic and social structures every 50 years. This principle was also reinforced by the Sabbath Year, which required debt cancellation every seven years. The modern Jubilee movement, inspired by these ancient texts, gained momentum with the Jubilee 2000 campaign, an international coalition that successfully advocated for the cancellation of $90 billion in debt owed by the world’s poorest nations, reducing their total debt to about $37 billion. The movement's legacy continued through the Jubilee Debt Coalition, which secured $130 billion in debt cancellation for lower-income countries between 2000 and 2015. In the United States, the 110th Congress considered the Jubilee Act for Responsible Lending and Expanded Debt Cancellation of 2008, which aimed to authorize full debt cancellation for eligible low-income countries and ensure that savings from debt relief were used for poverty reduction, while also promoting responsible lending and creditor transparency. The principles of Jubilee continue to inform contemporary efforts, with Jubilee 2025 emphasizing the interconnected crises of justice, ecology, and human dignity, calling for systemic change rooted in biblical ideals of liberation and restoration.
